awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Are variants under selection for disease resistance predictive of disease susceptibility across taxa?
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Since the 1970’s, 3 billion birds have disappeared from North America. Infectious disease is an important cause of bird mortality. Beginning in 1999, West Nile Virus rapidly spread across North America, primarily infecting birds and sometimes leading to their death. Over the past two decades, house sparrows have evolved resistance to West Nile Virus, but the mechanism is unknown. This project will identify the genetic mechanisms through which house sparrows have evolved resistance to West Nile Virus. Birds are important vectors for many diseases, and this will be the first project to characterize how birds adapt to West Nile Virus. The Fellow will use this information to predict whether other species of birds are susceptible to West Nile Virus. The Fellow will recruit and train underrepresented minority students at UC Santa Cruz, a Hispanic Serving Institute, to work on this project. The Fellow will also volunteer outreach and teach to diverse undergraduate and K-12 students, inspiring them to pursue STEM careers. 

This project will first generate RNA-seq from house sparrows previously infected by West Nile virus. These data will be used to identify candidate genes where expression or splicing is associated with West Nile viral load. Next, the Fellow will identify genetic variants that are under selection in wild house sparrow populations through DNA-seq of museum specimens. Specifically, the Fellow will sequence samples from multiple house sparrow populations before and after the introduction of West Nile Virus and determine whether adaptation is parallel in response to West Nile Virus. By limiting our scope to the candidate genes identified previously, this project will identify variants that are likely to mediate West Nile resistance. Finally, the Fellow will develop a West Nile virus susceptibility predictor based on these variants and assess its ability to predict susceptibility across avian taxa. The Fellow will be trained in state-of-the-art techniques to isolate DNA from museum samples and will develop a strong understanding of disease ecology. The Fellow will also lead sampling field trips of underrepresented minority students through CALeDNA, a community science initiative to monitor ecological diversity through environmental DNA.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We investigated how the interactions between genotypes and a changing environment resulted in evolution / extinction in two systems: steelhead trout and the heath hen.

Steelhead/rainbow trout are native to the rivers and streams of Western North America. They have two possible life history strategies: migrate to the ocean or remain in freshwater. Due to dam construction, water diversion, and pollution during the 20th century, it has become more challenging for steelhead to migrate. We sequenced DNA from steelhead museum samples from the turn of the 20th century as well as contemporary steelhead. In these steelhead, there is a region in their DNA which is strongly predictive of migration tendency. We found that contemporary steelhead have a weaker genetic tendency to migrate than steelhead from the turn of the 20th century. We propose that this is an adaptive response to migratory routes that have become more challenging to navigate.
 
Additionally, since the late 1800s, billions of domesticated hatchery trout have been stocked into California waterways. Despite previous research, it is unclear whether these hatchery trout have hybridized with natural populations of steelhead trout. With our historical samples, which were taken prior to most hatchery stocking, we are able to definitively answer this question. We find that contemporary steelhead have a small but statistically significant proportion of ancestry from hatchery trout, which varied from 0 to 10% in our samples, with most populations below 4% hatchery ancestry.
 
The heath hen was a prairie grouse that was hunted to extinction in 1932. For several decades heath hens surived only on the island of Martha's Vineyard. This species is one of the earliest for which their decline and eventual extinction was scientifically recorded. Before their extinction, they experienced multiple population rebounds despite no effort to breed the birds. We sequenced DNA from several Martha's Vineyard heath hen museum samples as well as their closest living relatives. We find these heath hens have a unique population history, showing signs of long-term small population size, consistent with this population's isolation on Martha's Vineyard. We propose that this small population size resulted in genomic purging, in which low-fitness alleles are removed from a population, and that this enabled the population rebounds observed prior to the heath hen's extinction. 
 
There is also interest in restoring a species with a similar ecosystem function as the heath hen (potentially through “de-extinction”) to the sandplains grasslands biome. This is a distant goal, and it would require beginning with a closely related living species and modifying its genome to be more like a heath hen. Given that these genetic modifications will be costly and time-consuming, it would be valuable to assess which genetic differences between the species are most important. To address this problem, we developed a computational method that is able to rank the functional importance of genetic variants based on evolutionary conservation, genomics context, and predicted impact on gene products.

Efforts were made throughout this award to increase representation in biology. To improve my mentorship skills, I enrolled in the equity-minded mentoring program, a six-part workshop series run by the Center for Innovations in Teaching and Learning at UC Santa Cruz. The program equips mentors with the skills needed to support mentees from underrepresented backgrounds. Then, I trained and supervised three undergraduates from backgrounds underrepresented in computational biology and ecology. One undergraduate became an author on a scientific paper. All three undergraduates are currently applying or planning to apply to graduate programs in biology.

I was an officer in the UC Santa Cruz Women in Science and Engineering (WiSE) group. As an officer with WiSE, I co-founded the GradPath program. GradPath pairs undergraduates considering applying to graduate school with graduate student mentors. GradPath continues to run, and has enrolled students during 5 academic quarters, with 105 mentoring pairs in total.

Finally, I acquired essential new research skills that have had a strong positive impact on my career.
